title: 'The Hundred draft can be a lottery despite best-laid plans,' says Simon Katich
text:
Simon Katich touched down in London on Thursday, three days before the inaugural Hundred draft. But really his preparation for the draft began more than three months ago, when he was unveiled as Manchester Originals head coach.

“There’s been a lot of planning around strategy and looking at options around different price bands tracking form and looking at all the data,” says Katich, who has been a coach since retiring five years ago from a playing career that included 56 Tests for Australia.

In July, he visited Manchester to begin draft planning, and has been thinking about how to build his squad ever since. “Between myself and all our support staff and analyst there’s been a fair bit of effort put in to try and get what we think will work on draft night.”

And yet there is an essential uncertainty to this process: for all the meticulous preparation, the night itself will still throw up unexpected challenges and opportunities. “You can have the best-laid plans but ultimately it can become a bit of a lottery on draft night because you can’t predict who wants who.”

From experiences in the Caribbean Premier League draft and the Indian Premier League auction – he was involved in the Knight Riders stable of franchises and is now Royal Challengers Bangalore head coach – Katich has learnt of the need to be flexible when the clock is ticking. “You’ve got to have backup plans,” he says. When a rival snares a player his team are seeking just before his turn to pick, “you might flip it to grab a different type of player” – getting a bowler, say, when the plan had been to recruit a batsman next pick.
